code.displayName: NHS Continuing Healthcare Decision Support Tool

ClinicalDocument.title: NHS Continuing Healthcare Decision Support Tool

td.content: Date of completion of Decision Support Tool:
Was the individual involved in the completion of the DST?
Was the individual offered the opportunity to have a representative such as a family member or other advocate present when the DST was completed?
If yes, did the representative attend the completion of the DST?

th.content: The contact details of the representative

td.content: Does the patient have the mental capacity to consent or dissent to the undertaking of the assessment?
If No, Has a Best Interests Decision has been made on behalf of the patient
If No, Has a Third Party with Lasting Power of Attorney (Welfare), given consent on behalf of the patient
If No, Has a Third Party appointed Welfare Deputy by the Court of Protection, given consent on behalf of the patient
The Independent Mental Capacity Advocate has been consulted

th.content: The contact details of the individual providing consent on behalf of the patient

td.content: Summary pen portrait of the individual's situation, relevant history and current needs, including clinical summary and identified significant risks, drawn from the multidisciplinary assessment:

tr.td:
Parkinsons disease
Lewy-Body Dementia
Bladder Tumour - 10 years ago
BCC removed last year
Frequent falls
Mrs Belinda Taylor has a diagnosis of Lewy Body dementia, this has caused communication, comprehension and mobility difficulties.
Mrs Belinda Taylor needs supervision when mobilising.

td.content: Individual's view of their care needs and whether they consider that the multidisciplinary assessment accurately reflects these:

tr.th: Information about whether and how the individual (or their representative) contributed to the assessment of their needs. If they were not involved, please record whether they were not invited or whether they were not invited or whether they declined to participate.

td.paragraph: Ms Dean declined to participate in this assessment.

th.content: The assessments and other key evidence that were taken into account in completing the DST, including the dates of the assessments:
Contact details of GP and other key professionals involved in the care of the individual

tr.th: Description of the level of need

td.paragraph: “Challenging” behaviour that follows a predictable pattern. The risk assessment indicates a pattern of behaviour that can be managed by skilled carers or care workers who are able to maintain a level of behaviour that does not pose a risk to self or others. The person is nearly always compliant with care.

tr.th: Evidence of the level of need

tr.td: Patient has fluctuating mental state. Daily episodes of restlessness and hallucinations which can last several hours. Patient becomes frustrated with inability to communicate needs

tr.th: Description of the level of need

td.paragraph: Cognitive impairment that could include marked short-term memory issues and maybe disorientation in time and place. The individual has awareness of only a limited range of needs and basic risks. Although they may be able to make choices appropriate to need on a limited range of issues they are unable to do so on most issues, even with supervision, prompting or assistance.

The individual finds it difficult even with supervision, prompting or assistance to make decisions about key aspects of their lives, which consequently puts them at high risk of harm, neglect or health deterioration.

tr.th: Evidence of the level of need

tr.td: Marked short term memory loss. Disorientation in time and place. Unable to assess basic risks; for example tries to get up and walk or get out of bed without assistance. Hence this puts him at a high degree of risks or falls. Lewy Body dementia diagnosed - deteriorating condition

tr.th: Description of the level of need

td.paragraph: Mood disturbance, hallucinations or anxiety symptoms, or periods of distress, which do not readily respond to prompts and reassurance and have an increasing impact on the individual's health and/or well-being.
Withdrawn from most attempts to engage them in care planning, support and/or daily activities.

tr.th: Evidence of the level of need

tr.td: Has regular hallucinations which cause him anxiety. He normally responds to prompts and reassurance and this does affect his health and emotionally wellbeing. Withdrawn from social situations and without intense encouragement from his family will not engage.

tr.th: Description of the level of need

td.paragraph: Communication about needs is difficult to understand or interpret or the individual is sometimes unable to reliably communicate, even when assisted. Carers or care workers may be able to anticipate needs through non-verbal signs due to familiarity with the individual.

tr.th: Evidence of the level of need

tr.td: He has great difficultly in expressing himself. He has word finding difficulties which carers need to interpret and this is achieved by familiarity. Sometimes people cannot understand his replies to questions. This is likely to deteriorate as his condition progresses.

tr.th: Description of the level of need

tr.td:
Completely unable to weight bear and is unable to assist or cooperate with transfers and/or repositioning. ORDue to risk of physical harm or loss of muscle tone or pain on movement needs careful positioning and is unable to cooperate. ORAt a high risk of falls (as evidenced in a falls risk assessment).
OR Involuntary spasms or contractures placing themselves and carers or care workers at risk.

tr.th: Evidence of the level of need

tr.td:
Diagnosis of Lewy body Dementia and Parkinson symptoms put him at high risk of falls. His mobility is unpredictable and needs close supervision at all times. He often forgets to walk with a frame.
Fall risk assessment score 16

tr.th: Description of the level of need

tr.td:
Dysphagia requiring skilled intervention to ensure adequate nutrition/hydration and minimise the risk of choking and aspiration to maintain airway. ORSubcutaneous fluids that are managed by the individual or specifically trained carers or care workers.
ORNutritional status “at risk” and may be associated with unintended, significant weight loss.
OR Significant weight loss or gain due to identified eating disorder. OR Problems relating to a feeding device (for example PEG.) that require skilled assessment and review.

tr.th: Evidence of the level of need

tr.td:
Malnutrition Universal Screening Tool (MUST): High Risk
Significant unintentional weight loss from diagnosis 12 months ago.
Loss of appetite needs a lot encouragement to eat and drink

tr.th: Description of the level of need

tr.td: Continence care is routine on a day-to-day basis; Incontinence of urine managed through, for example, medication, regular toileting, use of penile sheaths, etc. ANDis able to maintain full control over bowel movements or has a stable stoma, or may have occasional faecal incontinence.

tr.th: Evidence of the level of need

tr.td: Incontinence of urine mainly at night , wears pads. His continence is managed during the day with regular toileting.

tr.th: Description of the level of need

td.paragraph: Risk of skin breakdown which requires preventative intervention several times each day, without which skin integrity would break down.
Pressure damage or open wound(s), pressure ulcer(s) with ‘partial thickness skin loss involving epidermis and/or dermis', which is responding to treatment.
A skin condition that requires a minimum of daily treatment, or daily monitoring/reassessment to ensure that it is responding to treatment.

tr.th: Evidence of the level of need

td.paragraph: There has been pressure damage to heels and sacrum which has responded to treatment. Dermatitis to legs with a potential to ulcerate. Usually responds to treatment but requires regular reassessment.

tr.th: Description of the level of need

td.paragraph: Normal breathing, no issues with shortness of breath.

tr.th: Evidence of the level of need
Description of the level of need

td.paragraph: Requires the administration of medication due to: non-concordance or non-compliance, type of medication (for example insulin), or route of medication (for example PEG, liquid medication).
Moderate pain which follows a predictable pattern; or other symptoms which are having a moderate effect on other domains or on the provision of care.

tr.th: Evidence of the level of need

td.paragraph: Requires medication to be given needs encouragement to comply. If left alone would not take medication. Has moderate pain and this effects his ability to carry out personal care activities.

drugTherapiesandMedicationSymptomControl.title: 10. Drug Therapies and Medication: Symptom Control

tr.th: Description of the level of need

td.paragraph: No evidence of altered states of consciousness.

tr.th: Evidence of the level of need
Description of the level of need
Evidence of the level of need

otherSignificantCareNeedsSection2.title: 12. Other Significant Care Needs to be Taken into Consideration

paragraph.content: Drug Therapies and Medication - Symptom Control

tr.th: Views of the individual on the completion of the DST that have not been recorded above

td.paragraph: Mrs Belinda Taylor was present at the meeting. They have agreed to the content of the completed DST.

assessedLevelsofNeedSection2.title: Assessed Levels of Need (in the table below N/A means not applicable)

td.paragraph: Mrs Belinda Taylor has a high needs cognition, mobility and nutrition; and moderate needs in behaviour, psychological needs, tissue viability and drugs therapy and medication
Because of her needs and the impact this has on her health and wellbeing we recommend she is eligible for NHS Continuing Health Care.

th.content: Date of the CHC Scheduled Review

code.displayName: Drug Therapies and Medication - Symptom Control
